'"Monetize" is a terrible word that tacitly admits that there is no such thing as an "Attention Economy." You can't use attention as a medium of exchange. You can't use it as a store of value. You can't use it as a unit of account. Attention is like cryptocurrency: a worthless token that is only valuable to the extent that you can trick or coerce someone into parting with "fiat" currency in exchange for it. You have to "monetize" it – that is, you have to exchange the fake money for real money.' - @pluralistic

In-context learning in #transformers is one of those mysterious #ML phenomena that needs more attention (no pun intended) from #neuroscientists.

In-context learning is a phenomenon in large language models where the model "learns" a task just by observing some input-output examples, without updating any parameters.
"Simply by adjusting a “prompt”, transformers can be adapted to do many useful things without re-training, such as translation, question-answering, arithmetic, and many other tasks. Using “prompt engineering” to leverage in-context learning became a popular topic of study and discussion." (https://transformer-circuits.pub/2022/in-context-learning-and-induction-heads/index.html)

Interestingly, two recent works (H/T @roydanroy) showed that in-context learning (at least under certain conditions) match solutions found by gradient descent:
1) Transformers learn in-context by gradient descent: https://arxiv.org/abs/2212.07677
2) What learning algorithm is in-context learning? Investigations with linear models: https://arxiv.org/abs/2211.15661

In #neuroscience, synaptic plasticity is generally thought to be the mechanism underlying many of the behavioral improvements that are loosely referred to as learning.

Could in-context #learning be an alternative mechanism underlying at least some behavioral improvements? Given the suggested similarities of the #hippocampus representation learning and transformers (https://arxiv.org/abs/2112.04035), it'd be interesting to see the implications of in-context learning for our understanding of #memory formation in the hippocampus? #NeuroAI

title: Pluralistic: Tiktok’s enshittification (21 Jan 2023) – Pluralistic: Daily links from Cory Doctorow

last_post.content:
This whole essay is so damn good that it was hard to pick a pull-quote.

"This is enshittification: surpluses are first directed to users; then, once they're locked in, surpluses go to suppliers; then once they're locked in, the surplus is handed to shareholders and the platform becomes a useless pile of shit."

https://pluralistic.net/2023/01/21/potemkin-ai/#hey-guys

The first picture in my post is from Branko Grunbaum's excellent paper "Are your polyhedra my polyhedra?", which you can get here:

https://sites.math.washington.edu/~grunbaum/Your%20polyhedra-my%20polyhedra.pdf

The answer is "No: some of your polyhedra are a lot weirder than mine!"

For starters, even his polygons can be weirder!

(6/n, n = 6)

@tomruen also notes that you can tile the hyperbolic plane by regular octagons meeting 3 at each vertex. This gives a map from the hyperbolic plane to our 2-holed torus tiled by octagons. I believe this makes the hyperbolic plane into the universal cover of this 2-holed torus!

I think this means our hyperelliptic curve is an example of a 'modular curve'. Can someone here verify this and maybe describe how it works?

Tom Ruen's posts on this are here:

https://mathstodon.xyz/@tomruen/109725170965933688

(5/n)

GRAZE FOR MASTODON

Tried following someone on their profile only to be asked to sign in? Confusing, yeah?

The Graze for Mastodon extension by @jaredzimmerman helps negate this and allows you to interact with users, even on their own instances.

I've made a short video on how to install, setup and use this great tool.

Please #boost to help spread the knowledge and if you like the content I make, feel free to subscribe to the channel.

https://youtu.be/7rEk_iOKPNo

#MastodonTips #FediTips

It should be possible to describe this branched double cover of the Riemann sphere by polynomial equations of degree 5 or 6. It's an example of a 'hyperelliptic curve':

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyperelliptic_curve

An elliptic curve gives a branched double cover of the Riemann sphere by a Riemann surface of genus 1. A hyperelliptic curve is a branched double cover of the Riemann sphere by a Riemann surface of genus > 1. We have one with genus 2!

(4/n)

PIXELFED IN MASTODON?

Given the open nature of the #ActivityPub protocol, it is possible to pull in the Instagram alternative, #Pixelfed, into your Mastodon Home Timeline.
This is great for those looking for an alternative to Instagram, but not wanting to use yet another app.

Here is another short video on how this works and how you can use it yourself!

Please #boost to help spread the knowledge and if you like the content I make, feel free to subscribe to the channel.

https://youtu.be/iPq-NqtTEqU

@matthew_d_green's thread on dictionary passwords (https://ioc.exchange/@matthew_d_green/109727371662457774) reminded me of an experiment I want to run.

What if a program randomly selected 30 words and then let the user select the 14 they find most memorable in the order they prefer.

It would be less secure than 14 random words, but we can still define a safe bound on it by assuming the user is fully predictable. It's just combinatorics.

I wonder if the better memorability would make up for the required increase in length.

title: Report: Election Deniers in the 2022 Midterm Elections | RuralOrganizing.org

last_post.content:
I keep seeing this back-patting about how election deniers got clobbered in 2022 and we should celebrate. In a report by my friends at Rural Organizing (with me looking over their shoulder), using my No More Election Deniers dataset, they find reason to be cautious about this. Hundreds of election deniers, from Senate to statewide to state leg, won their elections handily, in very safe, very red seats. Large swaths of the country are now represented by election deniers.
https://ruralorganizing.org/report-election-deniers-2022-midterm-elections

Scientists generally want their research to be openly accessible to the public.

So what's stopping them?

One study of Berkeley faculty (N = 479) found that 71% supported open access to research, yet only 18% of articles published by the group were open access: "a journal having no cost to publish in was more important than having no cost to read".

via https://www.arl.org/wp-content/uploads/2023/01/2023.01.18-open-access-publishing-a-study-of-uc-berkeley-faculty-views-and-practices.pdf

title: What Companies Still Get Wrong About Layoffs

last_post.content:
Layoffs:
- don't save money
- don't improve company performance
- don't increase stock pricess
- destroy trust
- have huge impacts on health, well-being, and income of employees

So why do layoffs? It's a network effect: execs lay people off because other companies are doing it

I'm working myself through http signatures mastodon explanation. My current understanding

I want as much traffic signed as possible
One has a chicken and egg problem, because one needs to expose a public key to make requests as the server. For example, in order to fetch the public key of parties making requests.
Where do I put this public key? I'm currently leaning towards doing something similar to Mastodon with its actor "actor". This would mean that, I create an account "bovine" that represents the server.

Does anybody have any comments?

🌩️⚡️🔦 Laser-guided lightening

"When very high-power laser pulses are emitted into the atmosphere, filaments of very intense light form inside the beam. These filaments ionise the nitrogen and oxygen molecules in the air, which then release electrons that are free to move. This ionised air, called plasma, becomes an electrical conductor. The laser’s channels of energized particles helped guide the lightning strikes along the laser beam."
